title: What Is Creation?
description: The meta-principle: creation as the discipline of removing what obscures.

sections.text: What if creation isn't about adding?
sections.subtitle: Most people think to create is to produce. But some of the most creative acts are acts of removal.

sections.text: When you simplify, are you creating or destroying?
sections.explanation: A 500-line file becomes a 50-line abstraction. You removed 450 lines. You subtracted. Yet everyone agrees: you created something.

sections.caption: Michelangelo: "I saw the angel in the marble and carved until I set him free."

messages: He didn't add marble to create David.

sections.text: Creation is the discipline of removing what obscures.
sections.explanation: This is the foundation. Every principle, every practice, every pattern in CREATE SOMETHING builds on this insight. You're not building from nothingâ€”you're revealing a solution that was always possible.

sections.caption: Three things obscure truth in code: duplication, excess, and disconnection.

messages.label: DRY
messages.text: Remove duplication until the concept is clear.

messages.label: RAMS
messages.text: Remove excess until only the essential remains.

messages.label: HEIDEGGER
messages.text: Remove disconnection until the system coheres.

sections.text: The same concept expressed multiple times.
sections.explanation: Which version is canonical? Which is correct? The duplication creates noise that hides the signal. The concept itself becomes obscured.
What does this actually do? What's the core value? The excess creates confusion that hides clarity. The essential purpose becomes obscured.

sections.text: Parts that don't relate to the whole.
sections.explanation: How does this fit? What does it serve? The disconnection creates fragmentation that hides coherence. The system's purpose becomes obscured.

messages: Am I adding, or am I revealing?
What would I need to remove for this to be clearer?
Is this creation, or is this obscuring?

sections.prompt: What's one thing in your current codebase that's obscured?
sections.answer: Don't fix it yet. Just see it. Seeing comes before doing.

sections.explanation: Not to see code as additions and features. But to see code as revelation and removal. This shift in perception is the foundation. Everything else builds on it.
